model.hed: Top 20 Resorts in the Southern U.S.
model.dek: Condé Nast Traveler readers rate the top resorts in Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia, and West Virginia

memberComments.comment: One of the most lovely, romantic and relaxing destinations in the Southeast. Fantastic for golfers or just enjoying the beautiful surroundings. Bagpiper at sunset makes the setting complete. There's access to the spa at its sister property, The Cloister.

"Beautiful setting for a romantic weekend. The staff kept the bar open for our late arrival from New York and even had sandwiches waiting! World class dining and a wonderful spa. We still talk about the two-hour couples massage and can't wait to get back!"

"Great for secluded get-away without missing all the amenities. Outstanding golf course, hiking, fishing, ATV, clay shooting. My kids—ages 13, 11, and 8—love it when we take them along. Great playroom and movie theater along with indoor pool to keep all three occupied.  Food and service are excellent. Have visited the Lodge multiple times in past two years."

Staying in the historical area added an extra dimension to our visit to Williamsburg.  In the evening we'd stroll the streets after the crowds had gone and dine in the taverns.  We really felt like we were back in the 1700s except with all the modern amenities.

Staying in the Colonial Houses  is an amazing way to experience Colonial Williamsburg. Since we visited during the off season, there were times when we could walk out our door on Duke of Gloucester Street and actually feel as if it were 1774. It will be difficult to return there in the future and stay in 'regular' lodgings.
"Old Georgia meets modern cuisine! You have to play croquet!"
"Wonderful old-world feel. Celebrated family reunion/50th wedding anniversary there. Staff was superlative. Food excelled our imagination! Would recommend highly."

"This is another place in Charleston that has a special place in my heart.  My husband and myself were able to spend our first Thanksgiving here as well as our first wedding anniversary upon his return from Afghanistan.  The hotel was so accommodating and such a  wonderful experience with both stays.  We were able to have views of the bay and drinks down on the makeshift beach.  Both visits were greeted by extremely kind staff and provided an amazing stay.  I hope to return soon!"
"Nice rooms and great view of harbor and downtown Charleston. Fantastic sunsets."

The Grand Hotel is a romantic getaway on the eastern shore of Mobile Bay.  A pure southern charm experience.  Fairhope has all the arts and good food, with southern hospitality.  A great destination to stay during Mardi Gras festivities in Fairhope and of course the Fat Tuesday parade in Mobile.
We love the setting of this hotel and the overall comfort. Very good food.
Fabulous service away from the beach crowds but within walking distance of great shops and restaurants.
In a perfect location with much to do in surrounding area. Our condo had everything we needed.

Traditional, gracious, Southern hospitality at its finest in a beautiful setting. The Homestead's best asset is its efficient, accommodating, and welcoming staff. A 'must place to visit' any time of year.
An excellent experience, the facility is a little worn around the edges but wonderful service and great tradition.
Always a treat with gorgeous beachfront townhomes and plenty of amenities and activities to suit every member of any group. Food was excellent as well!
Wild Dunes is a wonderful all-inclusive resort that offers enough for a vacation that you would never have to leave the property except that it is outside another wonderful destination, Charleston.

The Williamsburg Inn is a beautifully kept inn that depicts upper scale life in colonial times yet with all the modern-day amenities and more. It is beautifully furnished and elegant. It is my favorite place to visit. We stay every year in the fall and enjoy the working fireplaces in the rooms, as well as Colonial Williamsburg.

Elegant. Classic southern hospitality. Very well maintained.  Large comfortable rooms.  Beautiful interiors and gardens.  Helpful and attentive staff.  The perfect headquarters for a stay in 18th-century Williamsburg.

One of best hotels we have ever stayed in.  The staff was outstanding, the food excellent, the grounds are beautiful and it's right next to Colonial Williamsburg.  The manager, Kate, is outstanding.  We will be back soon and often.

A home away from home--very comfortable and spacious rooms with a beautiful decor unlike other hotels. The service was spot on--very friendly and helpful and attentive. The food was wonderful, especially the expansive breakfast. My husband and I came to Williamsburg on our honeymoon 18 years ago. We liked it so much, we continue to come back and brought our daughter with us. She loves it there, too. The spa was calming, spacious, relaxing, comforting. The homemade tea sachets provided the finishing touch to an indulgent afternoon. I would totally recommend the hot stone massage--unlike any experience I have ever had.

items.name: The Lodge, Sea Island
items.description: Anchoring the end of the island's historic Avenue of Oaks, the decidedly English-style manor has tranquil views across the Sound and golf course and service more akin "to an intimate European hotel, with Southern charm" (think: "meeting your every need without being over the top or overly effusive.") Folks "love the sunset bagpiper" and personal butlers that can "draw you a rose petal bath." Golfers consider it a nirvana, but "couples will be equally enchanted."

fields.caption:
Of the several hotel options on Sea Island, Georgia, the Lodge is a favorite among golfers, surrounded by the fairways: “It’s like an intimate European small hotel, but with Southern hospitality, Atlantic beaches, and A-1 golf included.”







**Overall score: 96.8**







_See full rating information for **[The Lodge at Sea Island, St. Simons Island](/north-america/united-states/the-lodge-sea-island-little-st-simons-island-georgia)**_

fields.title: jekyll-island-club-hotel-exterior.jpg
fields.credit: Courtesy of Jekyll Island Club Hotel

items.name: Primland Resort
items.description: Located in Blue Ride Mountain, this resort is an escape for golfers and families. Situated on 12,000 acres of land, guests can opt to stay in one of the Lodge’s 26 rooms, or at Fairway Cottages and Primland’s Mountain Homes for a more private experience. With a challenging golf course and activities like ATV driving, tree climbing, mountain biking and stargazing, customers can enjoy a range of outdoor activities in addition to spa treatments and meals made of organic, local ingredients.

items.name: Barnsley Gardens Resort
items.description: Originally built as an Italianate villa, this "off-the-beaten-path resort" in the Blue Ridge Mountains now has a cluster of country cottages and is laid out to resemble an English country village, with ten acres of heirloom gardens. "Cottages are beautifully and uniquely decorated," with claw-foot tubs and handpicked reproduction furnishings, and have porches with rocking chairs or swings. Rice House serves prime beef, fresh fish, and wild game in an 1854 farmhouse with bullet holes from the Civil War—"the food is first-class, and it has a certain Barnsley flair to it." Activities include "the awesome golf course," designed by Jim Fazio, and a 17-station skeet-shooting course. "Staff are fabulous and the environment lends itself to a true escape from the daily grind."

items.name: Colonial Houses
items.description: "Step back in time" at this property "right in the middle of the action" in Williamsburg’s historic area. Overlooking Duke of Gloucester Street, brick walkways, and charming gardens, accommodations in original and reconstructed eighteenth-century buildings come with reproduction period furnishings as well as trundle beds and wood-burning fireplaces; some are tucked under the eaves, enchanting parents and children alike. "We really felt like we were back in the 1700s, except luckily we had all the modern amenities." Dine on regionally inspired contemporary cuisine at the Regency Room, including crabmeat Randolph, or enjoy barbecue specialties like pulled pork sandwiches at Huzzah! BBQ Grille. The staff "are beyond accommodating, and the concierge service is the best of the best."

items.name: Grand Hotel Marriott Resort Golf Club & Spar
The Inn at Palmetto Bluff, A Montage Resort
items.description: "This will be the best inn you’ve ever stayed at," by the May River amid acres of forests and ancient freshwater rice fields. "Superb Southern-style service" comes from staff "who make you feel like you are the first-ever guests." Rustic cottages are "quiet, secluded, immaculate, and spacious," with screened porches, white-wood doorways, vaulted ceilings, fireplaces, wide pine-plank floors, and hipped metal roofs. "You can do everything—golf, fishing, horseback riding, and a spa are some of the activities—or nothing, and be blissfully happy either way." The food at the River House Restaurant is "fantastic."

items.name: Keswick Hall
items.description: Set amid "magnificent countryside" near the Blue Ridge Mountains, this "intimate, charming" private estate conjures up a Tuscan villa. Public areas have overstuffed furniture with fringe and tassels, tables stacked with art books, and apple-filled porcelain bowls. Rooms—no two are alike—are subtly themed and may have four-poster canopy beds, bergère club chairs, and carpets with Aubusson designs; all overlook the gardens or the Arnold Palmer golf course. The 600-square-foot wine cellar Treble holds more than 5,000 bottles. Nightly turndown service by "friendly staff" includes slippers at your bedside and chocolates on your pillow. Fossett’s, named for Jefferson’s chief cook, offers a seasonal menu influenced by American regional cuisine. "Sunday brunch is delicious."

items.name: Charleston Harbor Resort & Marina, Mt. Pleasant
Pinehurst Resort
items.description: Includes The Carolina Hotel, The Holly Inn, and the Manor Inn (plus condos).

items.name: Ritz-Carlton Lodge, Reynolds Plantation
items.description: Set on "sprawling grounds," this "country club hotel" has slate floors, antler chandeliers, and stone fireplaces. "Request a room facing the lake—the views are superb"; amenities include feather beds, marble baths, and European bath products. Dine on Atlantic salmon with shrimp grits at Gaby’s by the Lake, which is "expensive but gorgeous," its deck looking out onto pine trees and the water. Service is "up to Ritz standards." The 26,000-square-foot spa has 19 treatment rooms.

fields.title: [Ritz-Carlton Lodge](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/ritz-carlton-lodge-reynolds-plantation-greensboro-greensboro-georgia)
fields.caption: Set on “sprawling grounds,” this “country club hotel” has slate floors, antler chandeliers, and stone fireplaces. “Request a room facing the lake—the views are superb”; amenities include feather beds, marble baths, and European bath products. Dine on Atlantic salmon with shrimp grits at Gaby’s by the Lake, which is “expensive but gorgeous,” its deck looking out onto pine trees and the water. Service is “up to Ritz standards.” The 26,000-square-foot spa has 19 treatment rooms.

items.name: The Sanctuary at Kiawah Island Golf Resort
items.description: "This is one of the best places for an active vacation." With 24 tennis courts, five golf courses, and six pools, this four-story oceanfront resort 30 minutes from Charleston has "one of the best combinations of accommodations, service, food, and golf on the planet." Rooms come with custom-made overstuffed furniture and have shuttered bathroom windows and oceanview balconies. "I felt like I was in a historic hotel with all the modern amenities." Jasmine Porch focuses on Southern specialties, while the Atlantic Room at the Ocean Course Clubhouse presents cedar-wrapped salmon with dill aioli. Family-friendly activities include ice-cream socials and sand-sculpture contests. "The service is spectacular, and everything is thoughtfully provided. It’s a once-in-a-lifetime experience that you must encounter."

fields.title: Sanctuary At Kiawah Island
fields.credit: Courtesy the Sanctuary At Kiawah Island

items.name: Sanderling Resort
items.description: Expect Outer Banks architecture like cedar-shake siding at this beachfront retreat where "the location makes it an ideal getaway." Accommodations are "coastal chic"—airy with simple bedding, chenille lounge chairs, and private balconies—and spread throughout three inns. A recent multimillion renovation added new eateries, including Kimball’s Kitchen, where locally sourced meat and seafood are as much of a draw as the views of the sound. The Beach House Lobby Bar and Sandbar are also new additions, with fresh-baked pastries on hand at the former, and poolside drinks at the latter. An award-winning spa goes beyond the usual offerings with yoga classes and bridal services. Staff are "exceptionally friendly, helpful, and welcoming."

items.name: The Cloister
items.description: "There is something for all ages" at this "truly family-friendly," Addison Mizner–designed, Mediterranean-style resort on a private island. Rooms with wood furniture, overstuffed chairs, exposed beams, and Turkish rugs showcase views of the Black Banks River and the ocean. Staff "make you feel like you’ve arrived in another era, where manners and gentility are still the norm." Seven restaurants offer a variety of options—from Southern dinners at the stately Georgian Room under gold and crystal chandeliers, to the rustic Italian restaurant, Tavola, where guests can interact with the chef as she tosses pizza, slices house-cured prosciutto, and bakes olive ciabatta. Take advantage of "tons of activities," including horseback riding; unwind at the "magnificent spa and fitness center," or enjoy a round of "fantastic golf."

items.name: The Greenbrier
items.description: Set on 6,750 acres in the Allegheny Mountains, this resort was founded in the 1800s as a cottage community but today offers falconry, kayaking, golf, and a casino—"there is so much to do." Its "charm and elegance" include Dorothy Draper–style interiors with neo-Baroque furniture. "Gorgeous eye-candy rooms are extremely well appointed" in antiques, floral fabrics, and black-and-white marble floors. Enjoy seafood, pasta, and Neapolitan pizzas at The Forum, or a mountain hot-stone massage at the spa, which uses minerals derived from the nearby sulfur springs.

items.name: Williamsburg Inn
items.description: "Everything is right" about this "very old-world" inn near Duke of Gloucester Street and Merchants Square, steps from Colonial Williamsburg’s Revolutionary City. Built by John D. Rockefeller, Jr., the whitewashed brick structure has tall Ionic columns, wrought iron railings, and an arched portico entrance. "Simply outstanding" guest rooms are decorated in floral, classic, or Restoration style with period furniture made from Honduras mahogany, original artwork, and handmade silk window treatments. Enjoy "elegant, gracious dining" at the Regency Room, where the American cuisine includes house specialties of Berkshire pork tenderloin schnitzel and crabmeat Randolph, and the decor incorporates crystal chandeliers and silk drapes. "The service and hospitality of the whole staff are second to none."

items.name: Williamsburg Lodge
items.description: Steps away from historic Colonial Williamsburg, brick buildings connected by covered walkways make up this "charming lodge" designed in the 1930s by the Rockefellers. Interiors are characterized by folk art, original bluestone floors, and cypress accents. "Gorgeous British colonial–style rooms have spa-like bathrooms," a palette of reds and blues, and quilted beds. At the restaurant, indulge in contemporary American cuisine that is "nothing short of gourmet," with an emphasis on Chesapeake seafood and local wines. "Staff, from the doorman to the desk help, are very helpful and gracious." The spa is "everything a spa should be" and includes aromatherapy rooms and whirlpools.
